DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Lower In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely reflecting follow-through selling from Wednesday's weaker close. Forecasts for more badly needed rain in Brazil, a leading soybean producer, added to the selling pressure in the soybean market this morning. In the wheat market, there were indications that the Soviet Union is seeking to buy European, rather than U.S. wheat, which prompted selling of wheat futures. Losses were limited, though by reports of new export sales of U.S. grains. The Agriculture Department said it had accepted bids from Iraq for 11,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices and Mexico was rumored to have bought nearly 205,000 metric tons of U.S. corn overnight. The soybean market had led Wednesday's decline, which analysts attributed to seasonal factors and to the temporary closing of the Panama Canal. Shipments of U.S. soybeans to Japan pass through the canal, which reopened today. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.12 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.38 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with March at $1.52} a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 2 cents lower with January at $5.73 a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly lower while pork futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The Agriculture Department announced this morning that its monthly cold-storage report, which was due out this afternoon, will be delayed until Dec. 27. Pork-belly futures had fallen sharply Wednesday on expectations that the report would show a large net increase in warehoused supplies of the commodity. Live cattle futures were .10 cent to .28 cent higher with February at 76.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 84.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent lower to .23 cent higher with February at 49.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent lower to .23 cent higher with February at 49.05 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures finished lower on Wednesday.
